cautionary_tales.title: Big Mickie's Hospital Adventure
cautionary_tales.content: 1998, middle of a bull market. Big Mickie's ignoring chest pains, popping antacids like they're M&Ms. 'Just stress,' he says. I'm watching him turn grey at his desk, and he's still trying to close deals. Next thing you know, he's face-down in the Goldman Sachs lobby. Three stents and one very angry cardiologist later, he learned his lesson. Now he's got a pacemaker that beeps during poker games.
cautionary_tales.lesson: Ignore the warning signs, and your body will shut down your business for you

success_stories.title: Miss Pearl's Prediction
success_stories.content: Miss Pearl walks into my office, points at my throat, says 'Get that checked, honey.' I thought she was crazy - felt fine. But she wouldn't let it go. Turned out to be early-stage thyroid issue. Caught it before it got serious. Now I never ignore Miss Pearl's 'feelings' about medical stuff.
success_stories.positive_outcome: Early detection saved months of treatment

cautionary_tales.title: Miss Pearl's Caddy Disaster
cautionary_tales.content: Miss Pearl kept putting off that transmission service. 'It's just a little slip, sugar.' Until her Caddy decided to give up the ghost right in the middle of the Mass Pike. Rush hour. August. 95 degrees. She was stuck there in her St. John suit for three hours. Now she's religious about maintenance.
cautionary_tales.lesson: Regular maintenance is cheaper than a tow truck and a ruined designer suit

success_stories.title: Big Mickie's Redemption
success_stories.content: After the Caddy incident, Big Mickie actually started listening. Got his BMW serviced on schedule, kept all the records. When he went to trade it in, dealer offered him top dollar. 'First time I made money on a car,' he said, beaming like he'd just closed a million-dollar deal.
success_stories.positive_outcome: Proper maintenance led to better resale value

cautionary_tales.title: Big Mickie's Creative Accounting Adventure
cautionary_tales.content: 2002, Big Mickie gets creative with his deductions. 'They'll never check,' he says. Guess who shows up? IRS with a magnifying glass. Three months of audits, penalties that made his eyes water, and his accountant nearly had a stroke. Now he keeps receipts for his receipts.
cautionary_tales.lesson: The IRS has no sense of humor and infinite patience

success_stories.title: Miss Pearl's Perfect Audit
success_stories.content: Miss Pearl walks into an audit with color-coded files, every receipt organized by date and category. The IRS agent actually smiled - I didn't know they could do that. In and out in 30 minutes. Now she teaches a little tax organization class at the community center.
